sections.title: Program Overview
sections.content:
The NIH Human Virome Program (HVP) is a Common Fund initiative established in 2023 to comprehensively characterize the human virome and elucidate its role in human health and disease.

## Mission
To systematically identify and characterize the viruses that inhabit the human body across diverse populations and body sites, and to understand their impact on human biology, health, and disease.

## Program Goals
**Develop standardized methods** for virome detection and characterization
**Create reference datasets** of the human virome across diverse populations
**Investigate virome-host interactions** in health and disease contexts
**Build collaborative infrastructure** for virome research
**Train the next generation** of virome scientists

sections.title: Funding & Structure
sections.content:
## Funding Details
The NIH Human Virome Program is funded by the NIH Common Fund with approximately $140 million allocated over 5 years (FY2023-2028).

## Program Structure
The program funds three main components:

**Virome Characterization Centers (VCCs)**: 5 major research centers focused on comprehensive virome profiling across diverse human populations and body sites.

**Functional Studies Projects**: 5 targeted research projects investigating specific aspects of human virome biology and virus-host interactions.

**Consortium Organization and Data Collaboration Center (CODCC)**: Coordination hub for administrative activities, data management, and cross-consortium collaboration.

sections.title: Leadership & Governance
sections.content:
## Program Directors
**Dr. Richard Conroy** (NIH Common Fund)
**Dr. Liliana Brown** (NIAID)
**Dr. Michael Fischbach** (Stanford University)
**Dr. Ramnik Xavier** (Broad Institute)

## Working Group
The NIH HVP Working Group comprises scientific leaders from multiple NIH Institutes and Centers, representing diverse expertise in virology, microbiology, and human biology.

## Governance Structure
The program operates through a Steering Committee with representatives from each funded center and project. Executive leadership is provided by elected co-chairs and key NIH officials. Working groups address specific scientific and operational challenges.

sections.title: Scientific Impact
sections.content:
## Expected Outcomes
**Comprehensive catalog** of human-associated viruses across diverse populations
**Standardized protocols** for virome characterization
**New tools** for viral discovery and functional characterization
**Insights** into virome's role in human health and disease
**Open data resources** for the broader scientific community

## Significance
This program represents the first coordinated, large-scale effort to systematically characterize the human virome across diverse populations and body sites. The insights gained will transform our understanding of the role viruses play in human biology and provide new paradigms for diagnosing, treating, and preventing viral-associated diseases.
